awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Discovering the hidden functional trait diversity of Bees (Apoidea) and predicting functional diversity impacts on rendered ecosystem services
awd_abstract_narration:
We often associate pollination with a few external characteristics in bees (e.g., hairiness & tongue length) but bees are complex organisms with a plethora of unstudied morphological and physiological traits (e.g., gut structure, muscular form, and thermal tolerance) that can strongly influence their effectiveness as pollinators. This project will link unstudied, internal morphological traits with bee physiological responses. At its core this work links structure and function with the functional role of bees as pollinators. MicroCT technology will be used to render high-resolution quantitative imagery of internal morphological traits. Honeybees will be used as a model system and the work will be expanded to obtain imaging and an analytical framework of 50 species of wild bees across multiple groups. By linking morphology and physiology with functional diversity, this work has the potential to shape how we think about and manage pollinator biodiversity. This work will provide research and training opportunities to six undergraduate students that will work on microCT imaging techniques, biological data science and experimental biology on the physiology of bees. 

This project will explore the associations between functional diversity and morphological and physiological traits that directly influence the ecosystem service of pollination provided by bees. The project uses microCT technology to image both honeybees and native wild bees over the course of two years. Specific emphasis is placed on internal morphological traits in relation to bee’s physiological responses (e.g., respiration and thermal tolerance) to environmental stress and thus ultimately impact a bee’s efficacy as a pollinator. The PI and undergraduate research assistants will conduct thermal tolerance and respiration assays on bees to determine potential links of functional trait morphology with important physiological responses. This work will provide workforce development opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bees and other insects provide the key ecosystem service of pollination. In order to better understand how this service functions, this work focused on understanding the functional traits associated with bees (both native bees and managed honeybees). Our lab in a small private liberal arts college worked closely with undergraduate students to better understand the physical traits of bees that make them excellent pollinators. This work resulted in multiple student research opportunities, professional development, and teaching materials for students and associated researchers. To date, we know that traits like hairiness (pilosity) and body size of bees can impact their efficacy as pollinators. We hypothesized that internal morphological traits and physiological traits also influence how effective bees can be as pollinators. We used microCT technologies to scan a honeybee’s internal morphology and CO2 respiration chambers to better understand a bee’s individual metabolism and functional physiological traits. We also used thermal tolerance assays to evaluate how effective bees can be under different increased and decreased temperatures. We completed these thermal assays and our study is the first to document how thermal tolerance and metabolism changes in a honeybee colony throughout the year.

 

We found that internal morphological traits can be measured for larger specimens of honeybees and bumble bees. However due to technological limitations we cannot measure internal morphologies of the majority of bee biodiversity because they are too small. Respiration also proved difficult to reliably measure due to an individual bee’s size and generation of CO2 gasses. We therefore recommend that future analyses measure CO2 respiration at the honeybee or bumblebee colony level rather than the individual level. We used three methods of evaluating CO2 results but their extremely different results make us question their reliability.

 

We were able to use thermal tolerance assays on honeybees but no other native bee species. The results of honeybee thermal tolerance however show a clearly distinct seasonal pattern. Darning summertime months (June-September) bees have larger trait plasticity and are able to thrive in extreme thermal ranges (+-20C). This contrasts with thermal tolerances in winter and spring months where thermal tolerance is limited to only a few degrees (+-5C). Our study measured how this pattern changed into fall and winter and spring months to give a big picture of annual variation in honeybee thermal tolerance. Due to our limited sample size we strongly recommend that this data be verified and reproduces before results are published.

 

Finally, we used these funds to develop resources within our institution. We constructed a state of the art bee apiary with different honeybee rearing method (e,g. Traditional Langstrof hives, observation hives and Slovenian hives). These hives serve to educate our student body as well as our community about honeybee functional traits, ecosystem services and view their unique behavior in a safe environment. Further out lab’s outreach and education efforts using the No Mow May program had extensive reach as we worked with nearly 200 different communities in 15 states to implement pollinator conservation initiatives in their own communities. Major metropolitan areas like Milwaukee, Madison and Chicago all participated in No Mow May initiatives initiated by our lab. Educating the general public about pollinator biodiversity and conservation is a major success of work supported by this grant. The PI also participated in developing local ordinances and state legislation aimed at protecting pollinators in Appleton and the state of Wisconsin.

            Bees play a major role pollination. Understanding their biodiversity, morphological and physiological traits is important to enhance their protection and conservation. Our work yields insight into the internal morphology, ecology and physiology of bees in our ecosystems. Future work can build on what we have started in our lab to understand bee physiology and morphology at finer resolution. This is especially important because much of the native bee biodiversity is smaller in size that what we studied here (honeybees and bumblebee species). We are thankful to the National Science foundation for funding this exploratory work.
